## Basics

### Header

#### Header


Here is a very usefull clickable hyperlink which is compact guide for R Markdown:
[click me](https://rstudio.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/rmarkdown-cheatsheet.pdf)

Carefull about spacing!

Chunks run from top to bottom.

"Library" the packages you are using. 

If knitting takes forever it probably because you are trying to output a huge dataframe.

These are global options for code chunks:

```{r setup, echo=T}
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = T,message=F,warning=F,error=T)
```

Set the local options with {r, ...} 

```{r, message=T,warning=F}
library(tidyverse)
```

Some of the important options are:

+ include = FALSE prevents code and results from appearing in the finished file. R Markdown still runs the code in the chunk, and the results can be used by other chunks.
+ echo = FALSE prevents code, but not the results from appearing in the finished file. This is a useful way to embed figures.
+ message = FALSE prevents messages that are generated by code from appearing in the finished file.
+ warning = FALSE prevents warnings that are generated by code from appearing in the finished.
+ error=TRUE will knit even with errors in your code
+ results='hide' to not show the code
+ eval=FALSE will not evaluate the chunk of code

1.
    ```{r}
    1+2
    ```
2.
    ```{r, echo=F}
    1+2
    ```
3.
    ```{r, results='hide'}
    1+2
    ```
4.
    ```{r, eval=F}
    1+"2"
    ```
5.
    ```{r, error=T}
    1+"2"
    ```
6. 
    ```{r, include=F}
    b<-5 
    ```

    ```{r}
    b 
    ```

### GGPLOT

```{r}
plot(x<--50:50,x^2,type="l")
```
```{r}
alpha=seq(0,2*pi,pi/100)
plot(cos(alpha),sin(alpha))
data.frame(alpha,X=cos(alpha),Y=sin(alpha))->df
#install.packages("esquisse")
#install.packages("miniUI")
ggplot(df) +
  aes(x = X, y = Y, color=alpha) +
  geom_path() #geom_point() geom_line()
```



```{r}

  geom_point(aes(x=Petal.Length,y=Petal.Width))
```

## Referencing
Citing a book [(@berlekamp2003winning] and an article @doi:10.1002/jgt.22573. If we do not cite them then whey will not appear unless we go through some hoops. Obtain bibtex info online then copypasta it into 1 file with bibliography.bib (or appropirately change the name). The bib file (and other files like pictures) use paths relative to the location of the Rmd file. Add to YAML with no spaces in front:

bibliography: bibliography.bib

link-citations: yes

The citations will be appended at the very end of the output file.
@book{tolkien2008hobbit,
  title={The Hobbit, Or, There and Back Again},
  author={Tolkien, J.R.R.},
  isbn={9781439527269},
  url={https://books.google.si/books?id=yM-MPwAACAAJ},
  year={2008},
  publisher={Houghton Mifflin}
}
The article @tolkien2008hobbit
